column2: What would you like to do?
column3: When did you do the experiment?
column4: What happened during the experiment?
column5: How did that impact your anxiety?
column6: Did you learn anything new from this experiment?
column7: What is a social situation where you struggle with self-attention and would be good for an experiment?
column8: What experiment could you set up to check how shifting attention away from yourself makes you feel?
column9: What do you predict might happen if you do that?
column10: And what is the worst that could happen if you pay less attention to yourself?
column11: If this happens, what can you do to support yourself?
column12: When would be a good time to try this out?
column13: Is there anything that could get in the way of doing this experiment?
column14: Is there something you can do to prevent this and increase the chances of carrying out the experiment?
column15: Please log your small win
column16: How has your work with attention shifting been going?
column17: How do you want to title this journal entry?

column3: When I had a work call on Wednesday morning

I noticed my attention going to focus on whether what I was saying made sense or what I was saying was stupid, but refocused it again on expeessing what I needed to. I also focused my attention on the points others on the call were making and listened to that.
column5: I was less anxious than usual

column15: I was on my course and I put into practice focussing on the tutor when I felt anxious. I started to feel anxious within the first 5 minutes and started to sweat profusely. I focussed in my tutor, ignoring my physical symptoms and how I looked, and it worked.  I was able to learn more and I did not sweat again during the course.

column16: Good, I've been paying more attention to why I feel certain ways in group situations
It has been going quite well

column15: Made eye contact and said hello to people whilst walking in the park. Actively tried to keep my attention on them rather than myself. It was nice to feel normal for a little while.

column3: Had a meal at John & Margery's
column4: I became very aware of the behaviour of others, rather than worrying about me the whole time. I realised that a lot of what was happening in the connections between people was driven by the stronger characters in the room. Sitting back and observing helped me feel empowered and confident (well, more so)
column5: I was less anxious than usual
column6: I now understand how putting my attention elsewhere can actually help me to feel calmer and be more helpful to others. I realised that others struggle too, which I hadn't noticed before because I was so self absorbed.

I've found it useful to focus my attention away from myself. Unfortunately catching where my attention is can be a hot and miss and my anxiety takes over before I can focus on something else.

column3: On a walk with the dog, I interacted with another dog walker.
column4: We exchanged smalltalk but I made sure that paid more attention to her than me.
column5: I was as anxious as usual
column6: Yes, in retrospect I've remembered things about the other walker and do not have any negative memories about my own behaviour. I would usually spend some time ruminating on my behaviour, but because I wasn't paying attention to that, I've only remembered things about the other person. So, while I may have been anxious in the situation, I didn't give myself any fuel for later feelings of anxiety about myself and things I may have done wrong. I count this as a success.

column15: I am currently travelling so I have taken the opportunity to engage in conversations with strangers and really consciously pull myself if I catch my attention shifting to concerns that I am boring them etc. rather than focusing on the other person.
